title: The Battle Against Benjamin
shortSummary: Judges 20 recounts the civil war between the tribes of Israel and the tribe of Benjamin following a grievous sin committed in Gibeah. The chapter details Israel's initial defeats, their seeking of God's counsel, and the eventual defeat and near destruction of Benjamin, highlighting the consequences of sin and the importance of seeking God's guidance in conflict.
timeline: c. 1375-1050 BC - Period of the Judges in Israel

keyCharacters.name: Levite
keyCharacters.description: The husband of the concubine who was slain; his testimony sparks the assembly and the call for justice against Benjamin.

keyCharacters.name: Phinehas
keyCharacters.description: Son of Eleazar and grandson of Aaron, he stands before the ark of the covenant to inquire of the LORD during Israel's battle decisions.

keyCharacters.name: Tribe of Benjamin
keyCharacters.description: One of the twelve tribes of Israel; they refuse to surrender the wicked men of Gibeah and engage in battle against the other tribes.

keyCharacters.name: Tribes of Israel
keyCharacters.description: The united tribes (except Benjamin) who gather to seek justice and fight against Benjamin for the evil committed in Gibeah.

definitions.definition: A woman who lives with a man but has lower status than his wife; in this chapter, the Levite’s concubine is tragically abused and killed.
Refers to skillful warriors who use their left hand, noted here for their exceptional ability to sling stones accurately.
The sacred chest representing God's presence among Israel, used here as the place where Israel seeks divine guidance.
A biblical term meaning wicked or worthless men, used here to describe the perpetrators of the crime in Gibeah.

outline.heading: Israel Assembles and Confronts Benjamin
outline.description: All Israel gathers to address the atrocity committed in Gibeah. The Levite recounts the crime, and Israel demands Benjamin surrender the guilty men, but Benjamin refuses, setting the stage for conflict.

outline.heading: First Two Battles and Seeking God's Counsel
outline.description: Benjamin fights fiercely, defeating Israel in two battles. After each defeat, Israel seeks the LORD’s guidance, demonstrating dependence on God’s direction even in warfare.

outline.heading: The Third Battle and Benjamin’s Defeat
outline.description: Israel employs a strategic ambush, and with God’s help, they defeat Benjamin decisively. The tribe is nearly wiped out, illustrating the severe consequences of sin and rebellion against God’s justice.

application: Seek God’s guidance earnestly in times of conflict and decision-making, trusting His wisdom over human strength.
Recognize the serious consequences of sin within the community and the need for righteous judgment to maintain holiness.
Commit to unity and accountability within the body of Christ, addressing sin firmly but with a heart for restoration.
Understand that God’s justice may require difficult actions but ultimately aims to uphold His covenant and righteousness.

keyVerses.text: And the children of Israel arose, and went up to the house of God, and asked counsel of God, and said, Which of us shall go up first to the battle against the children of Benjamin? And the LORD said, Judah shall go up first.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the importance of seeking God's direction before engaging in battle, emphasizing dependence on divine guidance.

keyVerses.text: And Phinehas, the son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron, stood before it in those days, saying, Shall I yet again go out to battle against the children of Benjamin my brother, or shall I cease? And the LORD said, Go up; for to morrow I will deliver them into thine hand.
keyVerses.significance: This verse demonstrates God's sovereignty in battle and His assurance of victory when His people obey.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD smote Benjamin before Israel: and the children of Israel destroyed of the Benjamites that day twenty and five thousand and an hundred men: all these drew the sword.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows that God actively intervenes in judgment against sin, underscoring the seriousness of rebellion within His people.
